instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message:
Hi,  

I have a Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. No Green light.  After cleaning up some corroded caps around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> it will boot from the battery and work fine.  It will not boot or charge.  Do I have bad I/O board?
Coming off the DC board I have 3.14v but when I connect it to the MB at J7000 I get a fluctuating voltage from 4v to 8v on pin 1.  Should I have more voltage coming from the I/O board.    I've tested every capacitor on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> for short but can't find one.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: The green light actually blinks every now and then. So I've searched all over and I can't find out what voltage I'm supposed to get from the I/O board.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: Hi Thx but what component should I test those pins on? <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 17/18 has 3.3 and pins 27/28 has 20.5.  This is with the Fluke set to continuity mode.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: I've been doing some reading on the forum.  Should pin 3 of MLB to LIO Power Cable Connector (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>) have 5v already? Or is that created after it boots?  I know I watched a video of Louis' that explained this. Damn memory.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0.12v so I really need to get that going first of course.  Just looking for direction if computer boots and works off battery but not charger and is not charging.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message:
From another post i see that I needed to test <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> on the DC IN board itself.

<CHIP>U6091</CHIP> Pin 5 (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>) = 0.04v
<CHIP>U6091</CHIP> Pin 1/2 (<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>) = .5v

Voltages at J9500

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.028v

<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> = .46v

DC board has pins 1/2 at 3.2v

So I know I need to get PP3v42 back to the DC board or get that working first.  The low voltage means a short somewhere but just on the PP3V42?   I'll look at every cap and resistor on that line then or should I be focused on something else?

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: Saw <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> looked bad so I replaced it.  Now it will boot from charger but no green light still.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: Ok now once I put the I/O cable on I get an orange light.  I'm going to put it all back and see if it will boot and charge.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message: FIXED!  One little resistor can do so much.  <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> was the culprit.

threads.title: Not Charging but works from battery H20 damage Macbook air
threads.message:
What I'd like to figure out is why that resistor created that situation and how I would have found it or even known to look for that.  Looks like it was on <SIGNAL>CHGR_SGATE_DIV</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_INRUSH</SIGNAL>
.  Well all I can say is that I was having an issue with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and that the computer would work on battery and not Charger so looks like I'll be looking into those two things above.  If anyone has some info to share please do.
